question: [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Struct: BytecodeViewerConfig] [Missing Validation] Are the PathBuf fields (module_binary_path, module_sourcemap_path, source_file_path) at lines 28-36 validated for correct file extensions (.mv, .mvsm, .move), or can attackers provide arbitrary file types? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Struct: BytecodeViewerConfig] [Relative Path Handling] Can an attacker provide relative paths in the config fields that resolve to unexpected locations based on the current working directory, bypassing intended access restrictions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Function: start_viewer()] [Config Mutation] Since start_viewer() takes &self at line 51, is there any risk of the config being modified during execution, or can the paths change between validation and use? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Struct: BytecodeViewerConfig] [Canonicalization Bypass] Are paths canonicalized before use, or can attackers use ./../../ sequences to bypass directory restrictions even if some path validation exists? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-bytecode-viewer/src/lib.rs] [Function: start_viewer()] [File Handle Leak] If multiple instances of start_viewer() are called concurrently, can file handle exhaustion occur from repeated fs::read() calls without proper cleanup? (Low)
